docs.title: ❌ Cancelled Sale
docs.text: Invoices that were canceled post-creation, maintaining traceability.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Audit trail
  • Stock reversal
  • Tax adjustments
  • Payment refund tracking
  • Document status updates

docs.title: Example Scenario
docs.text: A customer places an order but later cancels it (or fails to pay by the due date). The business cancels the sale order and any related invoice, reversing all related entries so that no sale is recorded.

docs.title: Flow Diagram
docs.text:
graph TD
    A[Start] --> B[Select Invoice]
    B --> C[Enter Cancellation Reason]
    C --> D[Reverse Stock]
    D --> E[Adjust Accounts]
    E --> F[Update Tax Records]
    F --> G[Generate Cancel Note]
    G --> H[End]

docs.title: 🧾 GST Composition Scheme – Impact on Transactions
docs.text: The GST Composition Scheme is a simplified tax regime for small businesses. This guide explains how it affects sales, purchases, ITC, and your billing software workflows, with practical examples and UI tips.

docs.title: 1. What is the Composition Scheme?
docs.text:
• Eligibility: Small taxpayers (turnover up to ₹1.5 crore; varies by state)
  • Tax Rate: Lower, fixed rates (e.g., 1% for traders, 5% for restaurants)
  • Returns: Simple quarterly returns (GSTR-4)
  • Restrictions:
    • Cannot collect GST from customers
    • Cannot claim Input Tax Credit (ITC)

docs.title: 2. Impact on Sale Transactions
docs.text:
• No GST on Invoice: Cannot show or collect GST from customers
  • Invoice Format: Must state: Composition taxable person, not eligible to collect tax on supplies
  • No Tax Breakdown: Invoice only shows total value, not GST
  • E-way Bill:
    • Required only for taxable goods
    • Will mention: "Bill of Supply" (not "Tax Invoice")
    • GST amount is not shown on the document

docs.title: 3. Impact on Purchase Transactions
docs.text:
• No ITC Claim: Cannot claim Input Tax Credit on purchases
  • Expense Booking: GST paid on purchases is added to cost (not claimable)
  • RCM:
    • Must pay GST under Reverse Charge if applicable
    • Cannot claim ITC on RCM paid

docs.title: 4. UI/Workflow Hints
docs.text:
• Customer Invoice:
    • Hide GST fields and tax breakdown
    • Add composition declaration on invoice
  • Purchase Entry:
    • Disable ITC eligibility fields
    • Show warning: No ITC claim allowed under Composition Scheme
  • RCM Handling:
    • Allow RCM flag, but show: RCM tax paid is not claimable as ITC

docs.title: 5. Example: Sale Invoice under Composition
docs.text: Field Value Invoice Type Sale (Composition) GST Shown? ❌ No Declaration Composition taxable person... ITC Allowed? ❌ No

docs.title: 6. Example: Purchase Entry under Composition
docs.text: Field Value GST Paid Yes (added to cost, not claimable) ITC Allowed? ❌ No RCM Paid Yes (if applicable, not claimable)

docs.title: 7. Pro Tips
docs.text:
• ✅ Check eligibility before opting for the scheme
  • ⚠️ Do not collect GST from customers
  • 📢 Always display the composition declaration on invoices
  • ❌ Do not claim ITC in returns or software

Reference: GST Composition Scheme – CBIC

docs.title: 🚚 Delivery Challan
docs.text: A non-monetary document issued during goods transportation.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• E-way bill integration
  • Stock tracking
  • Multiple destinations
  • Invoice conversion
  • Transport details

docs.title: Example Scenario
docs.text: A warehouse sends a bulk order to a retail store. A delivery challan is generated listing the items and quantities dispatched. This document is used to record legal movement of goods even if no sale is finalized.

docs.title: Flow Diagram
docs.text:
graph TD
    A[Start] --> B[Create Delivery Challan]
    B --> C[Add Items]
    C --> D[Enter Transport Details]
    D --> E{E-way Bill Required?}
    E -->|Yes| F[Generate E-way Bill]
    E -->|No| G[Skip E-way Bill]
    F --> H[Update Stock]
    G --> H
    H --> I[Print Challan]
    I --> J[End]

docs.title: 📋 Estimate
docs.text: A non-binding quote shared before order/invoice confirmation.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• No stock impact
  • Validity period
  • Multiple formats
  • Easy conversion to sale order or invoice
  • Revision tracking

docs.title: Example Scenario
docs.text: A contractor is asked to quote the cost for a renovation project. The contractor prepares an estimate detailing the work scope, materials, and costs. This estimate is not a binding invoice but can be accepted by the customer later.

docs.title: Flow Diagram
docs.text:
graph TD
    A[Start] --> B[Create Estimate]
    B --> C[Add Items & Prices]
    C --> D[Calculate Total]
    D --> E[Set Validity Period]
    E --> F[Customer Review]
    F -->|Approved| G[Convert to Order]
    F -->|Rejected| H[Mark as Closed]
    G --> I[End]
    H --> I

docs.title: 💸 Expense
docs.text: Non-inventory costs such as travel, rent, software, etc.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Category tracking
  • Recurring setup
  • Document attachment
  • Budget monitoring
  • Approval workflow

docs.title: Example Scenario
docs.text: An employee pays for business travel airfare and submits an expense report. The finance department enters this as an expense in the system. Expenses can include utilities, travel, office supplies, etc.

docs.title: Flow Diagram
docs.text:
graph TD
    A[Start] --> B[Create Expense]
    B --> C[Select Category]
    C --> D[Enter Amount]
    D --> E{Recurring?}
    E -->|Yes| F[Set Schedule]
    E -->|No| G[One-time Entry]
    F --> H[Attach Documents]
    G --> H
    H --> I[Get Approval]
    I --> J[End]

docs.title: 🧾 Purchase Invoice
docs.text: Bills received from vendors for stock/services bought.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• ITC tracking
  • Reverse charge handling
  • Stock updates
  • Payment scheduling
  • Bill verification

docs.title: Example Scenario
docs.text: A manufacturer orders raw materials from a vendor. When the materials arrive, the vendor sends a purchase invoice detailing items, quantities, and prices. This invoice records the company’s payable (liability) to the supplier.

docs.title: Flow Diagram
docs.text:
graph TD
    A[Start] --> B[Create Purchase Invoice]
    B --> C{ITC Eligible?}
    C -->|Yes| D[Add GST Details]
    C -->|No| E[Skip ITC]
    D --> F[Add Items]
    E --> F
    F --> G[Update Stock]
    G --> H[Schedule Payment]
    H --> I[Approve Invoice]
    I --> J[End]

docs.title: 🛒 Purchase Order
docs.text: A formal purchase request sent to vendors.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Budget validation
  • Vendor rate comparison
  • Approval workflow
  • Order tracking
  • Invoice matching

docs.title: Example Scenario
docs.text: A retail business needs new inventory and creates a purchase order listing items, quantities, agreed prices, and delivery date, then sends it to the vendor. The PO, once accepted, forms a contract obligating the supplier to deliver the goods as specified.

docs.title: Flow Diagram
docs.text:
graph TD
    A[Start] --> B[Create Purchase Order]
    B --> C[Select Vendor]
    C --> D[Add Items]
    D --> E[Budget Check]
    E --> F[Get Approvals]
    F --> G[Send to Vendor]
    G --> H[Track Order]
    H --> I[End]

docs.title: 🔄 Purchase Return
docs.text: Returning goods back to the supplier due to quality or excess.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Original bill linking
  • Quality documentation
  • ITC reversal
  • Vendor communication
  • Stock adjustment

docs.title: Example Scenario
docs.text: A bookstore receives a batch of books, but 10 copies are damaged. The bookstore returns these to the supplier. A purchase return transaction notes the returned items and typically generates a credit note from the supplier.

docs.title: Flow Diagram
docs.text:
graph TD
    A[Start] --> B[Select Purchase Invoice]
    B --> C[Choose Return Items]
    C --> D[Quality Report]
    D --> E[Generate Debit Note]
    E --> F[Update Stock]
    F --> G[Adjust ITC]
    G --> H[End]

docs.title: 🧾 Sale Invoice
docs.text: A final bill issued to a customer confirming the sale of goods/services with applicable taxes.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Seller and Buyer Details
  • Unique Invoice Number & Date
  • Itemized Line Items
  • Payment Terms
  • Totals and Taxes
  • Legal Record
  • GST/Non-GST sale support
  • Multi-mode payments
  • Discounts and taxes breakdown
  • Auto stock deduction
  • Links with Delivery Challan and Sale Order

docs.title: Example Scenario
docs.text: A retailer sells electronics to a customer on net-30 terms. After delivering the products, the retailer issues a sales invoice to the customer listing the items, quantities, prices, and payment due date. This invoice formally documents the sale and creates a legally binding payment request.

docs.title: Flow Diagram
docs.text:
graph TD
    A[Start] --> B[Create Sale Invoice]
    B --> C{GST Invoice?}
    C -->|Yes| D[Add GST Details]
    C -->|No| E[Skip Tax Details]
    D --> F[Add Items & Quantities]
    E --> F
    F --> G[Apply Discounts]
    G --> H[Calculate Total]
    H --> I[Select Payment Mode]
    I --> J[Update Stock]
    J --> K[Generate Invoice]
    K --> L[End]

docs.title: 📦 Sale Order
docs.text: A customer's confirmed order prior to invoicing. Acts as a commitment to deliver.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Pre-invoice transaction
  • Stock reservation (optional)
  • Partial invoicing
  • Custom delivery terms
  • Quote to order conversion

docs.title: Example Scenario
docs.text: An online customer places an order for furniture. The sales team creates a sales order specifying products, quantities, agreed prices, and expected delivery date. The sales order serves as a commitment and triggers inventory reservation and fulfillment planning.

docs.title: Flow Diagram
docs.text:
graph TD
    A[Start] --> B[Create Sale Order]
    B --> C[Add Customer Details]
    C --> D[Add Items]
    D --> E{Reserve Stock?}
    E -->|Yes| F[Block Inventory]
    E -->|No| G[Skip Reservation]
    F --> H[Set Delivery Terms]
    G --> H
    H --> I[Calculate Total]
    I --> J[Customer Approval]
    J --> K[Confirm Order]
    K --> L[End]

docs.title: 🔄 Sale Return
docs.text: When a customer returns goods post-sale. Adjusts both stock and accounts.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Original invoice linking
  • Stock adjustment
  • Tax reversal
  • Quality check integration
  • Return policy enforcement

docs.title: Example Scenario
docs.text: A customer returns a defective laptop within the return window. The business receives the item back, inspects it, and issues a credit note or refund. A sales return reverses part or all of the original sale, adjusting revenue and inventory.

docs.title: Flow Diagram
docs.text:
graph TD
    A[Start] --> B[Select Original Invoice]
    B --> C[Choose Items to Return]
    C --> D[Quality Check]
    D --> E[Calculate Return Amount]
    E --> F[Generate Credit Note]
    F --> G[Update Stock]
    G --> H[Adjust Accounts]
    H --> I[End]
